questions.question: Which landmark Supreme Court case established the principle of 'judicial review'?

answerOptions.rationale: This case established the 'separate but equal' doctrine.
Correct. This case established the Supreme Court's power to declare laws unconstitutional.
This case declared segregation in public schools unconstitutional.
This case guaranteed the right to an attorney for defendants in criminal cases.

questions.question: The 1954 case of Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka is a landmark decision because it...

answerOptions.rationale: This was the outcome of Plessy v. Ferguson, which Brown v. Board overturned.

answerOptions.text: Ruled that racial segregation in public schools was unconstitutional.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Court found that 'separate educational facilities are inherently unequal,' a major victory for the Civil Rights Movement.

answerOptions.text: Established the 'one person, one vote' principle.
answerOptions.rationale: This was established in later cases like Baker v. Carr.

answerOptions.text: Protected a student's right to free speech in school.
answerOptions.rationale: This was the issue in Tinker v. Des Moines.

questions.passage: In Gideon v. Wainwright (1963), the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that states are required under the Sixth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution to provide an attorney to defendants in criminal cases who are unable to afford their own.
questions.question: What right did the Gideon v. Wainwright case guarantee?

answerOptions.rationale: This was established in Miranda v. Arizona.

answerOptions.text: The right to a trial by jury.
answerOptions.rationale: This right is in the Sixth Amendment but was not the subject of this case.

answerOptions.text: The right to legal counsel, regardless of ability to pay.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The case ensured that indigent defendants have a right to a court-appointed lawyer.
Voting rights are protected by other amendments and laws.

questions.question: The case of Miranda v. Arizona (1966) led to the establishment of the 'Miranda rights.' What is the purpose of these rights?

answerOptions.text: To inform people of their right to vote.
answerOptions.rationale: Miranda rights are for criminal suspects, not voters.

answerOptions.text: To inform criminal suspects of their constitutional rights before they are questioned by the police.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This includes the right to remain silent and the right to an attorney.

answerOptions.text: To guarantee freedom of the press.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a First Amendment right.

answerOptions.text: To protect citizens from illegal searches.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a Fourth Amendment right.

questions.question: The Supreme Court's decision in Tinker v. Des Moines (1969), which involved students wearing black armbands to protest the Vietnam War, affirmed that...

answerOptions.text: Schools can ban any form of student expression they disagree with.
answerOptions.rationale: The case limited the ability of schools to ban expression.

answerOptions.text: Students do not lose their First Amendment rights to freedom of speech when they are on school property.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Court famously stated that students don't 'shed their constitutional rights at the schoolhouse gate,' as long as the expression does not substantially disrupt the educational environment.

answerOptions.text: All students must participate in patriotic activities.
answerOptions.rationale: This would violate freedom of speech and religion.

answerOptions.text: Student speech is not protected by the Constitution.
answerOptions.rationale: The case established that student speech is protected.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the Supreme Court's decision in Plessy v. Ferguson (1896)?

answerOptions.rationale: Slavery was abolished by the 13th Amendment.

answerOptions.text: It upheld the 'separate but equal' doctrine, providing a legal basis for segregation.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This decision was later overturned by Brown v. Board of Education.

answerOptions.text: It granted women the right to vote.
answerOptions.rationale: This was accomplished through the 19th Amendment.

answerOptions.text: It outlawed segregation in public schools.
answerOptions.rationale: It did the opposite; it legalized it.

questions.question: The case of McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) was important because it dealt with the relationship between federal and state power. The Court's decision...

answerOptions.text: Greatly limited the power of the federal government.
answerOptions.rationale: The decision expanded federal power.

answerOptions.text: Established that states could tax the federal government.
answerOptions.rationale: The decision established that states could not tax the federal government.

answerOptions.text: Affirmed that federal law is supreme to state law and that the federal government has 'implied powers.'
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The case confirmed the supremacy of the federal government and its ability to exercise powers not explicitly listed in the Constitution (like creating a national bank).

answerOptions.text: Gave states the power to regulate interstate commerce.
answerOptions.rationale: The power to regulate interstate commerce belongs to Congress.

questions.passage: The Dred Scott v. Sandford case of 1857 was a major decision leading up to the Civil War. The Supreme Court ruled that African Americans were not and could never be citizens of the United States. It also declared the Missouri Compromise unconstitutional, which further inflamed sectional tensions.
questions.question: What was a major consequence of the Dred Scott decision?

answerOptions.text: It peacefully resolved the issue of slavery.
answerOptions.rationale: It did the opposite, making a peaceful resolution much more difficult.

answerOptions.text: It strengthened the abolitionist movement and increased tensions between the North and South.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The ruling outraged abolitionists and many in the North, pushing the country closer to war.

answerOptions.text: It led to the immediate freedom of Dred Scott.
answerOptions.rationale: The ruling denied Dred Scott his freedom.

answerOptions.text: It was the first step in desegregating the nation.
answerOptions.rationale: The ruling was a major setback for racial equality.

questions.source: Summary of the Dred Scott v. Sandford decision.

questions.question: The Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade (1973) was a landmark case concerning what issue?

answerOptions.rationale: This was the subject of cases like Citizens United v. FEC.

answerOptions.text: The right to privacy and abortion
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Court ruled that a woman's right to an abortion was protected by the right to privacy under the Fourteenth Amendment. (Note: This decision was overturned in 2022).
This was the subject of cases like Regents of the University of California v. Bakke.
This has been the subject of several cases, such as Gregg v. Georgia.

questions.question: Which case guaranteed that a person must be informed of their constitutional rights, including the right to an attorney and the right to remain silent, upon arrest?

answerOptions.rationale: This case guaranteed the right to an attorney in court, but not the reading of rights upon arrest.
Correct. This case led to the creation of the 'Miranda warning' that police must read to suspects.
This case established judicial review.
This case dealt with student speech in schools.

questions.question: The case of Regents of the University of California v. Bakke (1978) was the Supreme Court's first major ruling on what controversial policy?

answerOptions.rationale: This was addressed in cases like Engel v. Vitale.
Correct. The Court's complex decision ruled that while racial quotas were unconstitutional, race could be considered as one factor among many in college admissions.
This has been addressed in cases like District of Columbia v. Heller.
This was addressed in United States v. Nixon.

questions.question: What was the significance of the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Nixon (1974)?

answerOptions.text: It confirmed that the President has unlimited executive privilege.
answerOptions.rationale: The decision did the opposite.

answerOptions.text: It ruled that the President's claim of executive privilege was not absolute and that he had to turn over taped conversations related to the Watergate scandal.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The ruling was a crucial check on presidential power and led directly to Nixon's resignation.

answerOptions.text: It decided that Richard Nixon had won the 1972 election fairly.
answerOptions.rationale: The case was about the Watergate investigation, not the election results.

answerOptions.text: It allowed the President to ignore subpoenas from Congress.
answerOptions.rationale: The ruling forced the President to comply with a subpoena.

Set 7.title: Social Studies ΓÇö Civics & Government Set 7

questions.question: Which of the following is considered both a right and a responsibility of a U.S. citizen?

answerOptions.rationale: Jury service is a civic duty and responsibility, but also a right ensuring trial by one's peers.
Owning property is a right, but it is not typically considered a civic responsibility.
Traveling is a right, but not a responsibility.
Attending school is often required by law up to a certain age, but it's more of a personal responsibility than a civic one.

questions.passage: The First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution protects several basic freedoms, including the freedom of speech, religion, the press, assembly, and the right to petition the government.
questions.question: The right to gather in a peaceful protest is protected by which First Amendment freedom?

answerOptions.rationale: While related, the right to gather is more specifically covered by another clause.
This protects the right of journalists and publications to report news and express opinions.
Correct. The freedom of assembly is the right to gather peacefully in groups.
This protects the right to worship or not worship as one chooses.

questions.question: Which of the following is a legal responsibility of every U.S. citizen?

answerOptions.rationale: Voting is a civic responsibility and a right, but it is not legally required.
Correct. All citizens who meet the requirements are legally obligated to pay federal, state, and local taxes.
Volunteering is a civic responsibility and is encouraged, but it is not legally required.
Staying informed is a responsibility of a good citizen, but it is not a legal requirement.

questions.question: The process by which a person not born in the United States voluntarily becomes a U.S. citizen is called...

answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Naturalization is the legal process for a foreign citizen to become a U.S. citizen.
Immigration is the act of moving to a country to live there permanently. Naturalization is the step after immigration to become a citizen.
Assimilation is the social process of becoming part of a different cultural group.
Registration, such as for voting or the selective service, is a process for citizens, not the process of becoming one.

questions.question: The Fourth Amendment to the Constitution protects citizens from...

answerOptions.rationale: This is protected by the Eighth Amendment.
This is protected by the Fifth Amendment ('pleading the fifth').
Correct. The Fourth Amendment requires law enforcement to have a warrant and probable cause to search a person's property.

answerOptions.text: The quartering of soldiers in private homes.
answerOptions.rationale: This is protected by the Third Amendment.

questions.passage: Civic participation includes a wide range of activities. While voting is the most common form, other activities include attending public meetings, contacting elected officials, volunteering for a campaign, or circulating a petition.
questions.question: According to the passage, which of the following is a way for citizens to participate in their government beyond voting?

answerOptions.rationale: This is a legal obligation, not a form of voluntary civic participation in the way the passage describes.
This is a legal duty, not an act of civic participation.
Correct. The passage lists this as a way to participate in civic life.
While a form of public service, the passage focuses on civilian forms of participation.

questions.question: The 'due process of law,' guaranteed by the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, ensures that...

answerOptions.text: A person can be imprisoned without a trial.
answerOptions.rationale: Due process guarantees the right to a trial.

answerOptions.text: The government must respect all legal rights that are owed to a person.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Due process means the government must act fairly and in accord with established rules before it can take away a person's life, liberty, or property.

answerOptions.text: Citizens are exempt from following laws they disagree with.
answerOptions.rationale: Citizens must follow all laws, regardless of personal agreement.

answerOptions.text: The government can seize private property for any reason.
answerOptions.rationale: The Fifth Amendment limits this power (eminent domain) to 'public use' and requires 'just compensation.'

questions.question: Why is it important for citizens to stay informed about political issues?

answerOptions.text: To be able to run for office themselves.
answerOptions.rationale: While being informed is important for running for office, this is not the primary reason for all citizens.

answerOptions.text: To make knowledgeable choices when voting.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. An informed electorate is essential for a functioning democracy.

answerOptions.text: To avoid paying federal income taxes.
answerOptions.rationale: Being informed does not exempt anyone from taxes.
There are no special benefits for being informed.

questions.question: The right to a 'speedy and public trial, by an impartial jury' is guaranteed by which amendment?

answerOptions.rationale: The First Amendment deals with freedoms of speech, religion, press, assembly, and petition.
The Fifth Amendment protects against self-incrimination and guarantees due process, but the right to a speedy trial is in another amendment.
Correct. The Sixth Amendment outlines the rights of the accused in criminal prosecutions, including the right to a speedy trial and a jury.
The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment.

questions.passage: Selective Service registration is the process by which the U.S. government collects names and addresses of men ages 18 through 25 to use in case a military draft is needed. Registration is a civic and legal responsibility.
questions.question: What does the passage imply about the Selective Service System?

answerOptions.text: That registering for the Selective Service is the same as enlisting in the army.
answerOptions.rationale: Registration does not mean enlistment; it is for a potential draft.

answerOptions.text: That only men who wish to volunteer for the military must register.
answerOptions.rationale: Registration is a legal requirement for almost all men in the specified age range, not just volunteers.

answerOptions.text: That the U.S. currently has an active military draft.
answerOptions.rationale: It implies that a draft is possible, but not that one is currently active. The system is in place 'in case' a draft is needed.

answerOptions.text: That the U.S. maintains a system for a potential military draft, and registration is legally required for eligible men.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. It is a legal responsibility that enables a draft if it were to become necessary.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the principle of 'equal protection under the law,' as guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment?

answerOptions.text: That all citizens must have the same income.
answerOptions.rationale: Equal protection relates to legal rights, not economic equality.

answerOptions.text: That the law must be applied to all people in the same way, without discrimination.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This principle was central to the Civil Rights Movement and means that states cannot unreasonably discriminate against individuals or groups.

answerOptions.text: That every citizen has the right to a government-appointed lawyer.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a right guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment in criminal cases, but it is not the meaning of 'equal protection.'

answerOptions.text: That all laws passed by Congress must be approved by a popular vote.
answerOptions.rationale: This describes a referendum, which is not how federal laws are made.

questions.question: Which action is a voluntary act of civic participation?

answerOptions.rationale: This is a legal requirement.
This is a legal requirement.

answerOptions.text: Serving on a jury when summoned
answerOptions.rationale: This is a legal requirement.

answerOptions.text: Participating in a town hall meeting
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Attending public meetings and expressing one's views is a voluntary and important part of being an engaged citizen.

questions.question: The division of power between a central national government and smaller state governments is known as...

answerOptions.rationale: This refers to the division of power among the legislative, executive, and judicial branches.
Correct. Federalism is the system where power is shared between the national and state governments.
This refers to the system that allows each branch of government to limit the powers of the other branches.
This is the principle that the government's authority is created and sustained by the consent of its people.

questions.passage: The Tenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution states: 'The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people.'
questions.question: The Tenth Amendment establishes which type of powers?

answerOptions.rationale: Delegated powers are those specifically given to the federal government.
Concurrent powers are those shared by both federal and state governments.
Correct. The Tenth Amendment is the basis for the reserved powers of the states.
Implied powers are not explicitly stated but are necessary for the federal government to carry out its delegated powers.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a power that is delegated specifically to the federal government?

answerOptions.rationale: This is a power reserved to the states.
This is primarily a state power, although the federal government sets some rules.
This is a power reserved to the states.
Correct. The power to declare war is explicitly given to Congress in the Constitution.

questions.question: Which of the following responsibilities is handled at the state level of government?

answerOptions.rationale: This is a federal power.
This is a federal power.
Correct. Education is a classic example of a power reserved to the states.
This is a federal power.

questions.question: A 'concurrent power' is a power that is...

answerOptions.text: Exercised only by the federal government.
answerOptions.rationale: This describes a delegated power.
This describes a reserved power.

answerOptions.text: Shared by both the federal and state governments.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. For example, both levels of government can levy taxes.

answerOptions.text: Denied to both the federal and state governments.
answerOptions.rationale: This describes a prohibited power.

questions.passage: The 'Supremacy Clause' in Article VI of the Constitution states that the Constitution, federal laws made pursuant to it, and treaties made under its authority, constitute the 'supreme Law of the Land.'
questions.question: What is the significance of the Supremacy Clause?

answerOptions.text: It establishes that state laws are superior to federal laws.
answerOptions.rationale: It establishes the opposite.

answerOptions.text: It means that if a state law conflicts with a federal law, the federal law takes precedence.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Supremacy Clause establishes the hierarchy of laws, with the U.S. Constitution and federal laws at the top.

answerOptions.text: It gives state governments the power to veto federal laws.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the concept of nullification, which is not supported by the Supremacy Clause.

answerOptions.text: It ensures that all states have identical laws.
answerOptions.rationale: The clause does not require states to have identical laws, only that they do not conflict with federal law.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best example of a concurrent power?

answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Both the federal government (Supreme Court, federal district courts) and state governments (state supreme courts, local courts) have their own court systems.
This is an exclusive power of the federal government.

answerOptions.text: The power to regulate interstate commerce.
answerOptions.rationale: This is an exclusive power of the federal government.

answerOptions.text: The power to ratify amendments to the Constitution.
answerOptions.rationale: This power is given to the states.

questions.question: The primary weakness of the Articles of Confederation, the first government of the United States, was that...

answerOptions.text: It gave too much power to the national government.
answerOptions.rationale: The Articles of Confederation created a very weak national government.

answerOptions.text: The states had too much power and the national government was too weak.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Constitution was created to rectify this by strengthening the federal government.

answerOptions.text: It did not allow for a legislative branch.
answerOptions.rationale: It did have a legislative branch (the Confederation Congress), but it was weak.

answerOptions.text: It created a powerful executive branch.
answerOptions.rationale: There was no separate executive branch under the Articles.

questions.question: The Supreme Court case McCulloch v. Maryland (1819) was significant because it...

answerOptions.text: Limited the power of the federal government to regulate the economy.
answerOptions.rationale: The decision actually expanded federal power.

answerOptions.text: Affirmed the principle of 'implied powers' and the supremacy of federal law over state law.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Court ruled that the federal government could create a national bank (an implied power) and that the state of Maryland could not tax it (federal supremacy).

answerOptions.text: Gave states the right to nullify federal laws.
answerOptions.rationale: The case established the opposite principle.

answerOptions.text: Established the principle of judicial review.
answerOptions.rationale: This was established in Marbury v. Madison.

questions.question: The 'Commerce Clause' of the Constitution gives Congress the power to regulate commerce 'among the several States.' How has the interpretation of this clause changed over time?

answerOptions.text: It has been consistently interpreted to give Congress very limited power.
answerOptions.rationale: The interpretation has generally expanded over time.

answerOptions.text: The Supreme Court has ruled that it does not apply to modern forms of commerce like the internet.
answerOptions.rationale: The Court has applied the Commerce Clause to modern commerce.

answerOptions.text: It has been interpreted broadly, allowing Congress to regulate many aspects of the national economy.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Landmark cases and legislation in the 20th century greatly expanded the definition of 'interstate commerce,' giving Congress wide-ranging regulatory power.

answerOptions.text: It has been amended to give all commercial regulatory power to the states.
answerOptions.rationale: The clause has not been amended in this way.

questions.question: A state passes a law legalizing a substance that is illegal under federal law. This situation creates a conflict based on which constitutional principle?

answerOptions.rationale: This is a conflict between federal and state authority, not between branches of the federal government.
This is not an issue of one federal branch checking another.
Correct. This is a classic example of a conflict in federalism, where a state law is at odds with a federal law, bringing the Supremacy Clause into question.

answerOptions.text: The Full Faith and Credit Clause
answerOptions.rationale: This clause requires states to respect the 'public acts, records, and judicial proceedings of every other state,' which is not the central issue here.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best example of a 'reserved power' of the states?

answerOptions.rationale: This is an enumerated power of the federal government.
This is an enumerated power of the federal government.

answerOptions.text: Making laws about marriage and divorce
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Family law is a power traditionally reserved for the states.

answerOptions.text: Entering into treaties with foreign countries
answerOptions.rationale: This power is exclusive to the federal government.

Set 8.title: Social Studies ΓÇö Civics & Government Set 8

questions.question: What is the first step for a bill to become a law in the U.S. Congress?

answerOptions.text: It is voted on by the full House or Senate.
answerOptions.rationale: A vote by the full chamber happens later in the process.

answerOptions.text: It is sent to the President for approval.
answerOptions.rationale: This is one of the final steps.

answerOptions.text: It must be introduced by a member of Congress.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. A bill can only be formally introduced by a Senator or a Representative.

answerOptions.text: It is reviewed by the Supreme Court.
answerOptions.rationale: The Supreme Court may review a law after it is passed, not before.

questions.passage: After a bill is introduced in Congress, it is sent to a specialized committee. The committee studies the bill, holds hearings, and may make changes. If the committee approves the bill, it is sent to the full House or Senate for debate.
questions.question: What is the role of a congressional committee in the lawmaking process?

answerOptions.text: To sign the bill into law.
answerOptions.rationale: Only the President can sign a bill into law.

answerOptions.text: To review and refine the bill before it is debated by the full chamber.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Committees are where the detailed work of studying, debating, and amending bills takes place.

answerOptions.text: To veto the bill if they disagree with it.
answerOptions.rationale: Only the President has the power to veto a bill.

answerOptions.text: To select the member of Congress who will introduce the bill.
answerOptions.rationale: Any member can introduce a bill.

questions.question: If the House of Representatives and the Senate pass two different versions of the same bill, what must happen before it can be sent to the President?

answerOptions.text: The President chooses which version to sign.
answerOptions.rationale: The President must be presented with one single, identical bill.

answerOptions.text: The Supreme Court decides which version is better.
answerOptions.rationale: The Supreme Court does not participate in the legislative process.

answerOptions.text: A conference committee is formed to create a compromise bill.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. A conference committee, made up of members of both chambers, resolves the differences to create one identical bill.

answerOptions.text: The bill is sent to the state governors for a vote.
answerOptions.rationale: State governors do not vote on federal legislation.

questions.question: What is a presidential veto?

answerOptions.text: The President's power to introduce a bill in Congress.
answerOptions.rationale: Only members of Congress can introduce bills.

answerOptions.text: The President's refusal to sign a bill into law, sending it back to Congress.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. A veto is a key check on the power of the legislative branch.

answerOptions.text: The President's ability to declare a law unconstitutional.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the power of judicial review, held by the Supreme Court.

answerOptions.text: The President's power to fire a member of Congress.
answerOptions.rationale: The President cannot fire members of Congress.

questions.question: An 'executive order' is a directive issued by the President that manages operations of the federal government. Executive orders have the force of law but do not require the approval of...

answerOptions.rationale: While the Cabinet may be consulted, their approval is not the key distinction.
The Supreme Court can review and strike down executive orders, but their pre-approval is not required.
Correct. Executive orders are a way for the President to direct the executive branch without needing to go through the full legislative process in Congress.
The Vice President's approval is not required.

questions.passage: A lobbyist is a person who is paid to represent the interests of a particular group or organization. They work to influence the decisions of public officials and lawmakers.
questions.question: What is the primary role of a lobbyist in the policy-making process?

answerOptions.text: To serve as an impartial advisor to lawmakers.
answerOptions.rationale: Lobbyists are advocates for a specific interest, so they are not impartial.

answerOptions.text: To provide information and advocate for their group's position on a particular issue.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Lobbyists present arguments, data, and their group's perspective to lawmakers to influence legislation.

answerOptions.text: To cast the deciding vote on a bill when Congress is tied.
answerOptions.rationale: Only members of Congress can vote on bills.

answerOptions.text: To report on the daily activities of Congress for a news organization.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the job of a journalist, not a lobbyist.

questions.question: How can an ordinary citizen play a role in the lawmaking process?

answerOptions.text: By vetoing a law they do not like.
answerOptions.rationale: Only the President can veto federal laws.

answerOptions.text: By contacting their representatives to express their views.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Contacting senators and representatives by phone, email, or mail is a key way for citizens to make their opinions known.

answerOptions.text: By introducing a bill in the Senate.
answerOptions.rationale: Only a senator can introduce a bill in the Senate.

answerOptions.text: By refusing to pay taxes on a law they disagree with.
answerOptions.rationale: Refusing to pay taxes is illegal and not a legitimate part of the lawmaking process.

questions.question: A 'filibuster' is a tactic that can be used in which chamber of the U.S. Congress to delay or prevent a vote on a bill?

answerOptions.rationale: The House has strict rules on debate time, which prevent filibusters.
Correct. The Senate's rules allow for extended debate, which can be used by a minority to block legislation.

answerOptions.text: Both the House and the Senate
answerOptions.rationale: The filibuster is a unique feature of the Senate.

answerOptions.text: Neither the House nor the Senate
answerOptions.rationale: The filibuster is a well-known, if controversial, Senate tactic.

questions.question: The process of 'gerrymandering' refers to...

answerOptions.text: The way political parties select their presidential candidates.
answerOptions.rationale: This is done through primaries and caucuses.

answerOptions.text: Drawing congressional district boundaries in a way that gives an advantage to one political party.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Gerrymandering can be used to create 'safe' districts for one party or to dilute the voting power of the opposing party.

answerOptions.text: A campaign finance system where corporations can donate unlimited funds.
answerOptions.rationale: This relates to campaign finance laws, not the drawing of districts.

answerOptions.text: The system used to count electoral votes in a presidential election.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the Electoral College system.

questions.passage: Public policy can be influenced by many factors. A major economic recession might lead to new government programs. A grassroots movement of citizens could pressure lawmakers to change a law. A landmark Supreme Court decision can reshape policy overnight.
questions.question: The passage suggests that the creation of public policy is...

answerOptions.text: A simple, straightforward process controlled by one person.
answerOptions.rationale: The passage illustrates that it is a complex process with many influences.

answerOptions.text: Influenced by a variety of factors, including economic conditions, citizen action, and court rulings.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The passage gives examples of economic, social, and legal factors that can shape public policy.

answerOptions.text: A process that never changes or adapts to new circumstances.
answerOptions.rationale: The passage shows that policy is created in response to changing circumstances.

answerOptions.text: Entirely determined by the results of public opinion polls.
answerOptions.rationale: While polls can be a factor, the passage lists other major influences.

questions.question: If a law is passed that seems to violate a right protected by the Constitution, what is the final step in determining if the law is valid?

answerOptions.text: The law is challenged in court and potentially reviewed by the Supreme Court.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The principle of judicial review allows the courts to determine the constitutionality of a law.

answerOptions.text: Congress must vote on the law a second time.
answerOptions.rationale: A second vote does not determine constitutionality.

answerOptions.text: The President issues an executive order to settle the matter.
answerOptions.rationale: An executive order cannot overturn a law's constitutionality.

answerOptions.text: A national referendum is held for all citizens to vote on the law.
answerOptions.rationale: There is no national referendum process for federal laws in the U.S.

questions.question: What is an 'appropriations bill'?

answerOptions.text: A bill that creates a new government agency.
answerOptions.rationale: This is an authorization bill.

answerOptions.text: A bill that actually provides the money for a government program.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. An 'authorization bill' may create a program, but the 'appropriations bill' is what allocates the funds to pay for it. This is part of Congress's 'power of the purse.'

answerOptions.text: A bill that proposes an amendment to the Constitution.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a constitutional amendment resolution.
This is a declaration of war.

Set 8.title: Social Studies ΓÇö Civics & Government Set 8

questions.passage: The U.S. Constitution establishes three separate branches of government: the legislative (Congress), the executive (President), and the judicial (Supreme Court). This division is known as the separation of powers.
questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the separation of powers?

answerOptions.text: To make the government work more efficiently.
answerOptions.rationale: While efficiency is a goal, the primary purpose is to prevent the abuse of power, which can sometimes be inefficient.

answerOptions.text: To prevent any one branch of government from becoming too powerful.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. By dividing power, the framers of the Constitution intended to create a system of checks and balances.

answerOptions.text: To ensure that the federal government is more powerful than state governments.
answerOptions.rationale: This relates to the concept of federalism, not the separation of powers.

answerOptions.text: To give the President the authority to make all final decisions.
answerOptions.rationale: The separation of powers is designed to limit, not expand, the President's authority.

questions.source: U.S. Constitution, Articles I, II, and III.

questions.question: Which branch of the U.S. government is responsible for making laws?

answerOptions.rationale: The Executive Branch, led by the President, is responsible for enforcing laws.
The Judicial Branch, led by the Supreme Court, is responsible for interpreting laws.
Correct. The Legislative Branch, also known as Congress, is responsible for writing and passing laws.
This is not one of the three constitutional branches of government.

questions.question: The President of the United States is the head of which branch of government?

answerOptions.rationale: The legislative branch is Congress.
Correct. The President is the head of the executive branch and is responsible for implementing and enforcing laws.
The judicial branch is headed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.
'Federal' describes the level of government, not a specific branch.

questions.question: The President's power to veto a bill passed by Congress is an example of...

answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The veto is a key way the executive branch can 'check' the power of the legislative branch.
Federalism is the division of power between the national and state governments.
Popular sovereignty is the principle that the government's authority comes from the people.
Judicial review is the power of the courts to declare laws unconstitutional.

questions.passage: The Supreme Court, through the principle of judicial review established in the case of Marbury v. Madison (1803), has the authority to declare laws passed by Congress or actions taken by the President to be unconstitutional.
questions.question: How does the power of judicial review allow the judicial branch to check the power of the other two branches?

answerOptions.text: By allowing judges to rewrite any law they disagree with.
answerOptions.rationale: Judges can only strike down laws as unconstitutional; they cannot rewrite them.

answerOptions.text: By giving the Supreme Court the ability to nullify laws that violate the Constitution.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This power ensures that the legislative and executive branches act within their constitutional limits.

answerOptions.text: By permitting the Supreme Court to veto any bill before it becomes law.
answerOptions.rationale: The power of veto belongs to the President, not the Court.

answerOptions.text: By allowing judges to impeach the President.
answerOptions.rationale: The power of impeachment belongs to Congress.

questions.source: Adapted from summaries of Marbury v. Madison.

questions.question: If Congress passes a bill, and the President signs it into law, but the Supreme Court later rules that the law is unconstitutional, what happens to the law?

answerOptions.text: The law is sent back to Congress for a revote.
answerOptions.rationale: Once ruled unconstitutional, the law is void. Congress would have to pass a new, constitutional law.

answerOptions.text: The law remains in effect until the next election.
answerOptions.rationale: A ruling of unconstitutionality invalidates the law immediately.

answerOptions.text: The law is no longer valid and cannot be enforced.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Supreme Court's ruling strikes down the law.

answerOptions.text: The President can override the Supreme Court's decision.
answerOptions.rationale: The President cannot override a Supreme Court ruling.

questions.question: How can the legislative branch check the power of the judicial branch?

answerOptions.rationale: Only the President can veto legislation, not court decisions.

answerOptions.text: By impeaching and removing federal judges.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The House can impeach, and the Senate can convict and remove judges from office.
Justices hold lifetime appointments and can only be removed through impeachment.
Amending the Constitution is a check, but it requires more than just the legislative branch.

questions.question: The President nominates a candidate for the Supreme Court. Which of the following represents a check on the President's power in this situation?

answerOptions.text: The House of Representatives must approve the nomination.
answerOptions.rationale: The Senate, not the House, has the power to confirm nominations.

answerOptions.text: The current Supreme Court justices must vote to accept the new member.
answerOptions.rationale: The current justices do not vote on new members.

answerOptions.text: The Senate must confirm the nomination with a majority vote.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The 'advice and consent' of the Senate is required to confirm a Supreme Court nominee, which is a check on the President's appointment power.

answerOptions.text: The candidate must be approved by a national popular vote.
answerOptions.rationale: There is no popular vote for Supreme Court justices.

questions.passage: Congress's 'power of the purse' refers to its constitutional authority over all federal spending. No money can be spent by the executive branch unless Congress has appropriated, or allocated, the funds.
questions.question: How is the 'power of the purse' a check on the executive branch?

answerOptions.text: It allows Congress to approve or deny funding for the President's programs and policies.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. By controlling the budget, Congress can limit the President's ability to carry out their agenda.

answerOptions.text: It gives Congress the power to declare the President's actions unconstitutional.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the power of judicial review, held by the courts.

answerOptions.text: It allows Congress to directly command the military.
answerOptions.rationale: The President is the Commander-in-Chief, though Congress has the power to declare war and fund the military.

answerOptions.text: It gives Congress the power to negotiate treaties with foreign countries.
answerOptions.rationale: The President negotiates treaties, which must then be ratified by the Senate.

questions.question: If the President vetoes a bill, Congress can override the veto. What is required for a successful override?

answerOptions.text: A simple majority vote in both the House and the Senate.
answerOptions.rationale: A simple majority is not enough to override a veto.

answerOptions.text: A two-thirds majority vote in both the House and the Senate.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is a high threshold that makes veto overrides difficult, representing a powerful check by the President.

answerOptions.text: A unanimous vote in both the House and the Senate.
answerOptions.rationale: Unanimous consent is not required.

answerOptions.text: The approval of the Supreme Court.
answerOptions.rationale: The Supreme Court is not involved in the veto override process.

questions.question: The members of which of the following are appointed for life?

answerOptions.rationale: Members of the House are elected for two-year terms.
Senators are elected for six-year terms.
Correct. To protect them from political pressure, federal judges, including Supreme Court justices, are appointed for life.
Cabinet members are appointed by the President and serve at the President's pleasure.

questions.question: Which of the following is a power reserved for the legislative branch?

answerOptions.rationale: This is a power of the President (executive branch).
Correct. Although the President is Commander-in-Chief, only Congress has the constitutional authority to declare war.

answerOptions.text: To grant pardons for federal crimes.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a power of the President (executive branch).

answerOptions.text: To interpret the meaning of laws.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the primary role of the judicial branch.

topics.title: Struggles for Equality in Modern America

quizzes.title: Social Studies ΓÇö Civil Rights movement and modern era Set 1

questions.question: Which event is widely regarded as the catalyst for the large-scale Civil Rights Movement of the 1950s and 1960s?

answerOptions.rationale: The March on Washington was a high point of the movement in 1963, not its starting point.
Correct. Sparked by Rosa Parks's arrest in 1955, the year-long boycott was the first major, successful protest of the modern Civil Rights Movement.

answerOptions.text: The passage of the Voting Rights Act
answerOptions.rationale: This was a major achievement of the movement in 1965, not its start.
The sit-ins in 1960 were an important tactic, but the movement had gained momentum with the bus boycott years earlier.

questions.question: The landmark Civil Rights Act of 1964 sought to...

answerOptions.text: Guarantee the right to vote for all citizens.
answerOptions.rationale: This was the primary goal of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

answerOptions.text: End segregation in public places and ban employment discrimination.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This was the most comprehensive civil rights legislation passed, outlawing discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.
Slavery was abolished by the 13th Amendment in 1865.
The act was designed to dismantle the 'separate but equal' doctrine.

questions.question: Cesar Chavez was a prominent figure in the mid-20th century who worked to improve the lives of...

answerOptions.rationale: His work was focused on agriculture, not urban factories.
Correct. Chavez co-founded the National Farm Workers Association and used nonviolent tactics like boycotts to fight for better pay and working conditions for farm laborers.
This was a focus of the feminist movement.

answerOptions.text: Native Americans fighting for tribal rights.
answerOptions.rationale: This was the focus of the American Indian Movement.

questions.passage: Title IX is a federal civil rights law in the United States that was passed as part of the Education Amendments of 1972. It prohibits sex-based discrimination in any school or any other education program that receives funding from the federal government.
questions.question: What has been one of the most visible impacts of Title IX?

answerOptions.rationale: This was primarily the result of Brown v. Board of Education.

answerOptions.text: The dramatic expansion of athletic opportunities for female students.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Title IX is widely credited with the massive growth of women's and girls' sports programs in high schools and colleges.

answerOptions.text: The creation of the Department of Education.
answerOptions.rationale: The Department of Education was created later, in 1979.

answerOptions.text: The establishment of a national curriculum.
answerOptions.rationale: Title IX deals with discrimination, not curriculum.

questions.question: The term 'Cold War' refers to the period of geopolitical tension after World War II between which two superpowers?

answerOptions.rationale: These two nations were allies.

answerOptions.text: The United States and the Soviet Union
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Cold War was an ideological, political, and economic struggle between the capitalist U.S. and the communist Soviet Union.
These nations were not the two primary superpowers in the post-WWII era.
These were the defeated Axis powers of World War II.

questions.question: The policy of 'containment' was the U.S. foreign policy strategy during the Cold War. What was the goal of containment?

answerOptions.text: To directly invade the Soviet Union and overthrow its government.
answerOptions.rationale: Containment was a policy of preventing the spread of communism, not of direct invasion of the USSR.

answerOptions.text: To prevent the spread of communism to other countries.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The idea was to 'contain' communism within its existing borders and prevent it from expanding.

answerOptions.text: To build a wall around all communist nations.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a literal interpretation; the policy was diplomatic and military, not physical.

answerOptions.text: To withdraw from all foreign affairs and focus on domestic issues.
answerOptions.rationale: This describes isolationism, which was the opposite of the containment policy.

questions.question: The Stonewall Uprising in 1969 is considered a major turning point in which social movement?

answerOptions.rationale: The key event for this movement was earlier, with Seneca Falls, and later with NOW.
This movement was focused on ending the war.
A key event for this movement was the publication of 'Silent Spring' and the first Earth Day.
Correct. The uprising against a police raid at the Stonewall Inn is seen as the catalyst for the modern gay rights movement.

questions.question: What was the primary goal of the 'Great Society' programs initiated by President Lyndon B. Johnson?

answerOptions.text: To win the space race against the Soviet Union.
answerOptions.rationale: This was a goal of President Kennedy's 'New Frontier.'

answerOptions.text: To eliminate poverty and racial injustice in the United States.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The Great Society included the creation of Medicare, Medicaid, Head Start, and the passage of major civil rights legislation.

answerOptions.text: To expand the U.S. military and its global presence.
answerOptions.rationale: While the Vietnam War expanded during his presidency, his domestic agenda had a different focus.

answerOptions.text: To dismantle the federal government and return all powers to the states.
answerOptions.rationale: The Great Society was a massive expansion of federal power and programs.

questions.passage: The Watergate scandal began with a break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters and ultimately led to an investigation that revealed a cover-up orchestrated by the White House. The scandal's resolution demonstrated that even the President is not above the law.
questions.question: What was the ultimate political consequence of the Watergate scandal for President Richard Nixon?

answerOptions.text: He was defeated in his re-election campaign.
answerOptions.rationale: He had already won re-election in a landslide before the scandal fully unfolded.

answerOptions.text: He was impeached by the House and removed from office by the Senate.
answerOptions.rationale: The House Judiciary Committee approved articles of impeachment, but he resigned before the full House could vote.

answerOptions.text: He resigned from the presidency to avoid certain impeachment and removal.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Nixon became the first and only U.S. President to resign from office.

answerOptions.text: He was cleared of all charges and served out his full term.
answerOptions.rationale: He was implicated in the cover-up and resigned.

questions.question: The term 'Reaganomics' refers to the economic policies of President Ronald Reagan in the 1980s. A central pillar of these policies was...

answerOptions.text: Increasing government spending on social programs.
answerOptions.rationale: Reagan sought to cut spending on many social programs.

answerOptions.text: Large tax cuts, particularly for corporations and the wealthy, with the goal of stimulating investment.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is a core component of 'supply-side' economics, which argues that cutting taxes on businesses and the wealthy will encourage them to invest, creating jobs and prosperity that 'trickle down' to everyone else.

answerOptions.text: Strengthening government regulations on businesses to protect the environment.
answerOptions.rationale: Reagan's policies focused on deregulation, not increased regulation.

answerOptions.text: Expanding the power of labor unions.
answerOptions.rationale: Reagan's administration took a strong stance against labor unions, most famously during the air traffic controllers' strike.

questions.question: The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 is a civil rights law that prohibits discrimination based on disability. Which of the following is a requirement of the ADA?

answerOptions.text: All television shows must be broadcast in black and white.
answerOptions.rationale: This is unrelated to the ADA.

answerOptions.text: Public accommodations, like restaurants and stores, must be accessible to people with disabilities.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The ADA mandates things like wheelchair ramps and accessible restrooms in public places.

answerOptions.text: All citizens must pass a physical fitness test to vote.
answerOptions.rationale: This is not a law and would be unconstitutional.

answerOptions.text: Employers can refuse to hire someone if they have a disability.
answerOptions.rationale: The ADA prohibits this kind of employment discrimination.

questions.question: The development of the internet and personal computers in the late 20th century led to what major societal shift?

answerOptions.text: A decline in the importance of education.
answerOptions.rationale: The new technologies have made education and digital literacy more important than ever.

answerOptions.text: The Information Age, with rapid access to information and global communication.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The internet has fundamentally changed how people access information, communicate, and do business.

answerOptions.text: A return to an agricultural economy.
answerOptions.rationale: The shift has been away from manufacturing and towards information and services.
The internet has greatly facilitated and increased global trade.

quizzes.title: Social Studies ΓÇö Civil Rights movement and modern era Set 1

questions.question: What landmark 1954 Supreme Court case declared that state-sponsored segregation in public schools was unconstitutional?

answerOptions.rationale: This 1896 case upheld the 'separate but equal' doctrine, which Brown v. Board of Education overturned.

answerOptions.text: Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This decision was a major legal victory for the Civil Rights Movement.
This pre-Civil War case ruled that African Americans were not citizens.
This case established the principle of judicial review.

questions.passage: The Montgomery Bus Boycott was a political and social protest campaign against the policy of racial segregation on the public transit system of Montgomery, Alabama. It was a seminal event in the Civil Rights Movement, sparked by the arrest of Rosa Parks on December 1, 1955.
questions.question: What was the primary method of protest used during the Montgomery Bus Boycott?

answerOptions.rationale: The boycott was based on the principle of nonviolent resistance.

answerOptions.text: A legal challenge that went directly to the Supreme Court.
answerOptions.rationale: While there were legal challenges, the main form of protest was the boycott itself.

answerOptions.text: Economic pressure through a mass refusal to use the bus system.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. African American citizens refused to ride the city buses for over a year, causing a severe economic impact.

answerOptions.text: A series of sit-ins at the bus station.
answerOptions.rationale: Sit-ins were a common tactic in other protests, but not the main method in this case.

questions.source: Adapted from historical accounts of the Montgomery Bus Boycott.

questions.question: Who was a prominent advocate of nonviolent civil disobedience and a key leader of the Civil Rights Movement?

answerOptions.rationale: Malcolm X initially advocated for Black separatism and self-defense, which differed from the nonviolent approach of other leaders.
Correct. Dr. King was the most famous proponent of nonviolent resistance, inspired by Mahatma Gandhi.
Huey P. Newton was a co-founder of the Black Panther Party, which advocated for armed self-defense.
Stokely Carmichael was a leader who became associated with the Black Power movement, which often had a more militant stance.

questions.question: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was a landmark piece of legislation. What did it do?

answerOptions.text: It granted women the right to vote.
answerOptions.rationale: This was the 19th Amendment, passed in 1920.

answerOptions.text: It outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. It was a comprehensive law that outlawed segregation in public places and banned employment discrimination.

answerOptions.text: It abolished the use of poll taxes in federal elections.
answerOptions.rationale: This was accomplished by the 24th Amendment.

answerOptions.text: It guaranteed a minimum wage for all workers.
answerOptions.rationale: Minimum wage is established by separate labor laws.

questions.question: The purpose of the march from Selma to Montgomery in 1965 was to campaign for...

answerOptions.rationale: While school desegregation was a goal, this march had a more specific focus.
Correct. The march was a protest against the obstacles that prevented African Americans from registering to vote.
Fair housing was the goal of a later campaign and the Civil Rights Act of 1968.

answerOptions.text: An end to the Vietnam War.
answerOptions.rationale: The anti-war movement was separate from this specific civil rights protest.

questions.passage: The 'sit-in' movement, which gained national attention in 1960 in Greensboro, North Carolina, was a form of direct action that involved one or more people occupying an area for a protest, often to promote political, social, or economic change.
questions.question: What was the goal of the sit-ins at segregated lunch counters?

answerOptions.text: To demand higher wages for restaurant workers.
answerOptions.rationale: The protests were about civil rights, not wages.

answerOptions.text: To challenge and overturn the policy of racial segregation in public accommodations.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. By sitting at 'whites-only' counters, protesters directly challenged the injustice of segregation.

answerOptions.text: To protest the quality of the food being served.
answerOptions.rationale: The protests were not about the food itself.

answerOptions.text: To get the restaurants shut down.
answerOptions.rationale: The goal was to integrate the restaurants, not to close them.

questions.question: What did the Voting Rights Act of 1965 accomplish?

answerOptions.text: It lowered the voting age to 18.
answerOptions.rationale: This was the 26th Amendment.

answerOptions.text: It gave women the right to vote.
answerOptions.rationale: This was the 19th Amendment.

answerOptions.text: It outlawed discriminatory voting practices, such as literacy tests.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The act was designed to overcome legal barriers at the state and local levels that prevented African Americans from exercising their right to vote.
The Electoral College was established by the Constitution.

questions.question: The 'Little Rock Nine' were a group of African American students who faced intense opposition when they...

answerOptions.text: Organized a sit-in at a Woolworth's lunch counter.
answerOptions.rationale: This describes the Greensboro sit-ins.

answerOptions.text: Attempted to enroll in the previously all-white Central High School in Arkansas.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. President Eisenhower had to send federal troops to escort the students and enforce the Brown v. Board of Education ruling.

answerOptions.text: Marched for voting rights from Selma to Montgomery.
answerOptions.rationale: This was a different event in the movement.

answerOptions.text: Founded the Black Panther Party in Oakland.
answerOptions.rationale: This was a different group of activists with a different focus.

questions.passage: The concept of 'Black Power,' which gained prominence in the late 1960s, represented a shift for some in the Civil Rights Movement. It emphasized racial pride, economic empowerment, and the creation of political and cultural institutions for Black people.
questions.question: How did the Black Power movement differ from the earlier focus of the Civil Rights Movement led by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.?

answerOptions.text: It rejected the idea of racial equality.
answerOptions.rationale: Black Power sought equality, but often through different means, emphasizing self-determination.

answerOptions.text: It focused more on self-sufficiency and racial pride, and sometimes rejected the goal of integration in favor of Black separatism.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. While Dr. King focused on integration and nonviolence, the Black Power movement often had a more nationalistic and assertive stance.

answerOptions.text: It was a movement exclusively focused on gaining voting rights.
answerOptions.rationale: The movement had broader goals, including economic and cultural empowerment.

answerOptions.text: It completely rejected all forms of political protest.
answerOptions.rationale: The movement used various forms of protest, though they were sometimes more confrontational.

questions.question: What was the purpose of the Freedom Rides in 1961?

answerOptions.text: To test a Supreme Court decision that had declared segregation on interstate buses and in bus terminals unconstitutional.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Civil rights activists, both black and white, rode buses into the segregated South to challenge the lack of enforcement of the Supreme Court's ruling.

answerOptions.text: To transport voters to the polls in Southern states.
answerOptions.rationale: This was a goal of other initiatives, like Freedom Summer, but not the Freedom Rides.
The Freedom Rides were focused on civil rights, not the war.

answerOptions.text: To demand the integration of the U.S. military.
answerOptions.rationale: The military had been officially desegregated by President Truman in 1948.

questions.question: The March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom in 1963 is most famous for...

answerOptions.text: The bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church.
answerOptions.rationale: This tragic event happened in Birmingham, not at the March on Washington.

answerOptions.text: The passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
answerOptions.rationale: The march helped build support for the act, but it was passed the following year.

answerOptions.text: Martin Luther King Jr.'s 'I Have a Dream' speech.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This iconic speech was a defining moment of the Civil Rights Movement.

answerOptions.text: The start of the Montgomery Bus Boycott.
answerOptions.rationale: The boycott began in 1955.

questions.question: The Kerner Commission, appointed by President Lyndon B. Johnson, was created to investigate what?

answerOptions.text: The assassination of John F. Kennedy.
answerOptions.rationale: This was the Warren Commission.

answerOptions.text: The causes of the race riots in American cities in the mid-1960s.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The commission's report famously concluded that the nation was 'moving toward two societies, one black, one whiteΓÇöseparate and unequal.'
The Watergate scandal occurred in the 1970s.

answerOptions.text: The effectiveness of the New Deal programs.
answerOptions.rationale: The New Deal was a response to the Great Depression in the 1930s.
